title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Kansas in 2020?
preds: Like SC, the GOP has an edge here but not much of one.
at this point, I'm following the crowd on this one

Kansas is done with the GOP
Kansas is a very red state. That’s not likely to change until way past the departure of the baby boomer generation.

Trump is way ahead in Kansas. This will definitely affect the down vote.

Bollier, the Democrat in this race, has been running neck and neck with the Republican in the race,  Marshall.  Kansas has not had a Democratic senator in 100 years. But this year might be the exception. Marshall has campaigned as classic Trumpian.  Bollier has run as a moderate.  Republicans still outnumber Democrats by 2 to 1 in the state but the state, like other states has a sizable and growing number of independents.   Add to that the fact that Bollier's campaign is very well financed and she is using that to her advantage.  Her ads have been spot on.  Given Trump's recent debate performance that might be enough to push Bollier over the edge and become the first Democratic senator from Kansas in 100 years.

Most election prediction orgs. have this seat as either 'Likely Republican' or 'Lean Republican'.  Some recent polls have been close: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_election_in_Kansas According to this source the last Democrat (newly) elected to the Senate from Kansas was in 1930: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_senators_from_Kansas https://www.newsweek.com/kansas-polls-marshall-bollier-1522879
The DNC has not won a Senate race in Kansas since 1972.
https://www.newsweek.com/kansas-polls-marshall-bollier-1522879 It is the quote on Cook Political in this article. They go deep into the weeds with their analysis.
There hasn't been a democrat senator in KS for > 50 years.
Carry on down the dust pipe

Marshall hasn't been down in a poll since June (though there have not been many) and Kansas is about as Red a state as they come. With no incumbent in the race, it's not super surprising neither candidate has a demanding lead, but when the rubber hits the road the GOP candidate will almost definitely get a boost on the ballot given the historical trends in the area. In fact, Dems haven't won a seat there since 1932! He also has the support of a lot of powerful organizations. The one exception, though, is Donald Trump, who has thus far refused to interfere in the election despite Senate Republicans' requests. However, voters for Trump are unlikely to vote for any Democratic candidate, and it is highly likely that if the situation does not improve Trump will give into pressure and endorse him. Basically, though it's close in the polls, it is difficult to see a clear path to victory for the Dem candidate without using the word 'miracle.'
Had Kris Kobach gotten the GOP nod, this seat would be very much in play. But as he lost, chances have diminished significantly for democrats to pick up this seat.
